author: Hannah Graham
title: 'We are 100% committed', Northern Powerhouse chief says as he pledges to fight for our economy
text:
'We are 100% committed', Northern Powerhouse chief says as he pledges to fight for our economy 15:30, 7 Aug 2016 Northern Powerhouse Minister Andrew Percy insisted the Government is fully behind the initiative championed by George Osborne Shares Get daily news by email Andrew Percy, MP for Brigg and Goole, was appointed as the new Northern Powerhouse minister 
The minister tasked with making the Northern Powerhouse a reality has insisted that the Conservative Government remains dedicated to the initiative — and claimed that the vote for Brexit has brought the region “a world of opportunities”. 
Andrew Percy, the Northern Powerhouse Minister, said he was “100% committed” to promoting the region’s economy. 
Mr Percy replaced James Wharton, MP for Stockton South, in the role in July. The move came soon after Chancellor George Osborne stepped down, leading some to call the future of the powerhouse vision into question, as it had been seen by many as Mr Osborne’s ‘pet project’. 
But the new minister said the Government is still committed to bringing economic growth in the North in line with that in London and affluent areas of the South East. 
He said: “The economic potential of the North of England is huge. Investors around the world can already see that for themselves, with foreign direct investment in the area more than doubling over the past two years. 
“But we need to go further. If we can reduce the productivity gap between London and the South East and the rest of the country by half, it could add £150bn to our economy. 
“That’s why we are 100% committed to supporting the northern economy, as part of our wider industrial strategy to deliver an economy that works for everyone across the country.” Video loading Click to play Tap to play The Live Event you are trying to watch is either unavailable or has not started Please refresh this page in your browser to reload this live event video 
The minister claimed that the recent vote to leave the EU could prove beneficial to the North — despite fears that the move could cost our region huge sums. 
Last month, MPs pointed out that the North East was due to receive almost £800m in European cash, and treasury ministers were forced to admit that Government could not guarantee the region would get comparable funding outside the union. Neil Hall/PA Wire Chancellor George Osborne 
But Mr Percy said: “The Brexit vote has opened up a world of opportunities for businesses in the North of England and we must seize them to become a great powerhouse of the future.” 
The MP for Brigg and Goole, in Yorkshire, added: “As Minister for the Northern Powerhouse, and a proud northerner, I can ensure the our voice is heard in the corridors of Whitehall.” 
And he insisted that the “key to the North’s success” lay in further devolution. 
The devolution deal offered to the North East, which would create a mayoral authority in the region and give local politicians great powers over certain areas and funding, is currently on hold. Read More Devolution deal shelved following Brexit uncertainty as North East leaders demand reassurances 
Last month, the leaders of seven North East councils voted to approve the devolution deal, which will guarantee £30m a year for the region to spend as well as control of a £3.4bn pool of investment cash, but only subject to assurances from Government on funding agreements. 
Mr Percy said: “Key to the North’s success is also to further devolve power from Westminster to local people, through our ground-breaking northern devolution deals and extra governance through elected mayors.”
